questions.text: A 20-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of intellectual and behavioral abnormalities and abnormal movements of his extremities. His mother reports that he often hits his head and limbs against furniture. He is unable to walk without support and speaks in unclear 2-word phrases. Examination shows multiple bruises on the forehead and several healing wounds over the fingers. There is increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum uric acid concentration. The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to also be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine concentrations are increased in patients with defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which causes phenylketonuria (PKU). Although this condition can cause intellectual abnormalities and abnormal movements due to seizures, it does not cause hyperuricemia or self-injurious behavior. Instead, other features, such as growth retardation, dermatitis, or a musty body odor, would be reported. Phenylalanine concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Orotic acid concentrations are increased in patients with uridine monophosphate synthase deficiency (orotic aciduria) or ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Orotic aciduria can cause developmental delay, but it does not cause motor symptoms, self-injurious behavior, or hyperuricemia. OTC deficiency would cause features of hyperammonemia (e.g., vomiting, somnolence, asterixis). Orotic acid concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenosine monophosphate and its derivates such as deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP) accumulate in patients with adenosine deaminase deficiency, which causes severe combined immunodeficiency. This condition manifests with failure to thrive and severe, recurrent infections in the first year of life. Deoxyadenosine trisphosphate does not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Branched-chain amino acids (isoleucine, leucine, and valine) accumulate in patients with maple syrup urine disease, which manifests during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, ketonuria, and sweet-smelling urine. Branched-chain amino acids do not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

There are 20 proteinogenic amino acids, which can be classified according to the physical properties of their side chains (polarity, charge). The amino acids with aromatic side chains appear in red here, while the branched-chain amino acids are in blue. Polar, uncharged amino acids include the three amino acids with a hydroxyl group on their side chain, serine, threonine, and tyrosine, which often undergo post-translational modification (phosphorylation), as well as the two derivates of positively charged amino acids aspartate and glutamate, asparagine and glutamine, both of which have a carboxamide group on their side chain.

E) CORRECT:

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) is a substrate in the purine salvage pathway that accumulates in patients who have HGPRT deficiency. The inability to regenerate purine nucleotides also leads to an excess of guanine and hypoxanthine bases, which are instead metabolized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, leading to hyperuricemia. The hyperuricemia seen in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can be treated by inhibiting xanthine oxidase with allopurinol or febuxostat, but this does not affect the neurological or behavioral features of this condition.
Image Description:

Purine nucleotides are degraded in several steps into uric acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Purine nucleotides (e.g., AMP, IMP, XMP, and GMP) are converted into purine nucleosides. This conversion occurs through hydrolytic cleavage of the phosphate residue and is catalyzed by nucleotidases.

Purine nucleosides are then cleaved into free bases (e.g., hypoxanthine, xanthine, and guanine) by nucleoside phosphorylases.

Xanthine is then oxidized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, the uric acid is partially reabsorbed, and the rest is excreted in the urine.

F) INCORRECT:

Cytosine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by defects in the purine salvage pathway and results in increased de novo purine synthesis; it does not increase the production of pyrimidines.
questions.hint: This boy has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive condition caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) that manifests with hyperuricemia, spasticity, dystonia, developmental delay, and self-injurious behavior.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the activity level of several different enzymes in human subjects from various demographic groups. An elevated level of activity of phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase is found in one of the study subjects. This patient is most likely to have which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of cystathionine synthase results in homocystinuria, which causes an accumulation of homocysteine in tissues and joints. This can lead to lens dislocation, atherosclerosis, bone deformities (elongated bones, kyphosis), and intellectual disability. Homocystinuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

B) CORRECT:

PRPP synthetase catalyzes the production of PRPP, a substrate for de novo purine and pyrimidine synthesis (i.e., adenosine monophosphate (AMP), guanosine monophosphate (GMP), and uridine monophosphate (UMP)). When purines (AMP, GMP) are degraded, they are metabolized into xanthine and finally uric acid. Thus, increased activity of PRPP synthetase causes an overproduction of purines and subsequent uric acid. Excess uric acid leads to the accumulation of monosodium urate crystals within the joints, causing acute inflammatory monoarthritis.
Image Description:

Biosynthesis of the nucleotide skeleton is an energy-intensive process that must be tightly regulated.
The key enzyme, glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, is activated by PRPP and inhibited by ADP, ATP, GDP, and GTP.

Not shown here: High levels of ATP promote the formation of GMP, whereas high levels of GTP promote the formation of ATP. Adenylosuccinate synthetase is inhibited by AMP, and IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by GMP (negative feedback inhibition).

C) INCORRECT:

Maple syrup urine disease is an autosomal recessive disease caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex, which leads to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., valine, leucine, and isoleucine). It manifests during the neonatal period with poor feeding, failure to thrive, ketonuria, and sweet-smelling urine. Maple syrup urine disease is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

D) INCORRECT:

Alkaptonuria is a disorder of tyrosine catabolism caused by deficient activity of homogentisic acid dioxygenase, which catalyzes the degradation of homogentisate to 4-maleylacetoacetate. This leads to the accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisic acid in the serum and the tissues, resulting in ochronosis with subsequent arthritis and degenerative changes in the vertebral column. Alkaptonuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, or rarely, tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency. It leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the CNS, resulting in intellectual disability, seizures, growth retardation, and pale skin/hair. Phenylketonuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.
questions.hint: Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase (PRPP synthetase) is an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of nucleotides and converts ribose 5-phosphate into phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with Crohn disease comes to the physician for evaluation of her immunosuppressive therapy. She has had recurrent flares since her diagnosis. Physical examination shows two shallow ulcers on her oral mucosa. The physician considers adding azathioprine to her medication regimen. A deficiency of which of the following enzymes would diminish the therapeutic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Xanthine oxidase converts hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. It also converts 6-MP into the inactive metabolite 6-thiouric acid. Deficiency of xanthine oxidase would divert 6-MP to other enzymes for metabolism, leading to increased levels of active metabolites and increased toxicity. This effect is observed when 6-MP or azathioprine are co-administered with the xanthine oxidase inhibitors allopurinol or febuxostat.

B) INCORRECT:

Thymidylate synthase converts deoxyuridine monophosphate to deoxythymidine monophosphate. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agent 5-fluorouracil. It is not involved in the metabolism of 6-MP.

C) INCORRECT:

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase converts ribose 5-phosphate into phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). PRPP is required for purine salvage and will ultimately be converted to inosine monophosphate, a process that can be inhibited by the azathioprine metabolite 6-MP. This enzyme is not involved in the metabolism of azathioprine or 6-MP.

D) CORRECT:

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) converts free purine bases (guanine and hypoxanthine) into purine nucleotides (GMP and IMP). It also converts the azathioprine metabolite 6-MP into thio-inosine monophosphate, which is the molecule directly responsible for the drug's cytotoxic effects. HGPRT deficiency would lead to a decreased conversion of 6-MP into its active metabolite, thus limiting the effectiveness of the drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Dihydrofolate reductase converts dihydrofolate into tetrahydrofolate. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agent methotrexate. It is not involved in the metabolism of 6-MP.

F) INCORRECT:

Adenosine deaminase converts adenosine into inosine. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agents cladribine and pentostatin, which both structurally resemble adenosine. Adenosine deaminase is not involved in the metabolism of azathioprine or its metabolite 6-MP.
questions.hint: Azathioprine is converted nonenzymatically to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), which is subsequently metabolized into its active forms (6-thioguanine nucleotides) by an enzyme that plays an important role in the purine salvage pathway.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. A urine pregnancy test is positive. A pelvic ultrasound shows a normal appearing uterus with an empty intrauterine cavity and a minimal amount of free pelvic fluid. Treatment with methotrexate is begun. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decrease in guanylate, the conjugate form of guanosine monophosphate (GMP), would be expected in patients taking mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) and ribavirin. These medications inhibit IMP dehydrogenase, which converts inosine monophosphate (IMP) to xanthosine monophosphate (which is then converted to GMP by xanthylate aminase). However, MTX inhibits pyrimidine base synthesis and would not decrease guanylate.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in thymidine monophosphate (TMP and dTMP) would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, which catalyzes the enzymatic reaction that forms dTMP (deoxythymidine monophosphate). Thus, a patient taking methotrexate would have decreased rather than increased levels of dTMP.

C) CORRECT:

Dihydrofolate reductase reduces dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, which acts as a methyl group shuttle for thymidylate synthase. Thymidylate synthase builds thymine bases, converting deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP). Therefore, inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase by MTX results in a decreased concentration of thymine-containing deoxyribonucleosides (i.e., dTMP), which are essential precursors for DNA synthesis, and an increased concentration of dUMP. In the case of ectopic pregnancy, as seen in this patient, ineffective DNA synthesis blocks the growth and development of the fertilized egg, typically leading to a rapid decrease in Î²-hCG levels within one week.

Other medications that inhibit dihydrofolate reductase and therefore have similar effects to MTX include trimethoprim (an antibiotic) and pyrimethamine (an antiparasitic).

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which catalyzes the enzymatic reaction that forms dTMP (deoxythymidine monophosphate), leading to an increase in upstream precursor molecules like PRPP. PRPP would also be increased in patients taking de novo purine synthesis inhibitors (e.g., 6-mercaptopurine, azathioprine).
Image Description:

Biosynthesis of the nucleotide skeleton is an energy-intensive process that must be tightly regulated.
The key enzyme, glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, is activated by PRPP and inhibited by ADP, ATP, GDP, and GTP.

Not shown here: High levels of ATP promote the formation of GMP, whereas high levels of GTP promote the formation of ATP. Adenylosuccinate synthetase is inhibited by AMP, and IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by GMP (negative feedback inhibition).

E) INCORRECT:

Increase in tetrahydrofolate polyglutamate, the biologically active form of folate, would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, the enzyme responsible for activating folate. Therefore, a decrease in tetrahydrofolate polyglutamate would rather be seen in patients taking MTX.
questions.hint: Methotrexate (MTX) is the medical treatment of choice for uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy. It is an antifolate that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase.
